This will help you maintain control and sensitivity to any changes in the ground. 2. **Use the Tip of the Cane**: Extend the cane in front of you, allowing the tip to make contact with the ground. The tip of the cane is designed to be sensitive to changes in the surface, such as bumps, dips, or obstacles. 3. **Listen for Changes**: As you walk, pay close attention to any changes in the sound or sensation of the cane tip hitting the ground. A sudden change in sound or resistance indicates the presence of an obstacle. 4. **Adjust Your Path**: If you detect an obstacle, stop and adjust your path around it. Use your other senses, such as hearing and touch, to navigate around the obstacle safely. 5. **Practice with Yuki**: Since Yuki is your guide dog, practice walking with her to become more familiar with her movements and how she responds to obstacles. This will help you both work together more effectively. 6. **Stay Alert**: Always stay alert and focused while walking. This will help you quickly detect any obstacles and react appropriately. By following these steps, you can effectively use your cane with Yuki to detect obstacles ahead and navigate safely.

If you haven't, you can do this at the check-in counter. Then, proceed to the baggage drop-off area to check in your luggage. 2. **Security Check**: Next, you will need to go through security screening. This involves removing any metal items from your person and placing them in a bin. You will also need to remove your shoes and any electronics from your carry-on bags. Be prepared to have your belongings and yourself scanned. 3. **Boarding Pass**: Ensure you have your boarding pass with you. This will be used to verify your identity and allow you to board the plane. 4. **Gate Check**: After security, follow the signs to the gate where your flight is departing from. The gate number will be displayed on the screens or posted on the wall. 5. **Boarding**: When it's time to board, listen for the announcement or look for the gate agent who will direct passengers to the plane. Follow the instructions to proceed to the aircraft. 6. **Seating**: Once you are on the plane, find your assigned seat. The flight attendants will assist you in finding your seat and stow your carry-on bag in the overhead compartment. 7. **Safety Briefing**: Listen to the safety briefing given by the flight attendants. This will include instructions on how to use the seatbelt, oxygen masks, and other safety equipment. 8. **Takeoff**: After the safety briefing, the plane will begin to taxi to the runway and take off. Enjoy your flight! If you have any questions or need assistance at any point, don't hesitate to ask the airport staff or flight attendants. They are there to help you.

Place the pot or pan directly on the cooker, as induction cookers do not require a burner. 3. **Use Compatible Cookware**: Only use cookware that is compatible with induction. Look for the "induction" or "microwave" symbol on the cookware. 4. **Avoid Overheating**: Monitor the temperature and avoid overheating, as this can cause the cooker to malfunction. 5. **Keep a Safe Distance**: Maintain a safe distance from the cooker while it is in use to prevent burns. 6. **Turn Off the Cooker**: Always turn off the cooker when finished cooking and unplug it if necessary. 7. **Clean Regularly**: Clean the cooker surface regularly to prevent any buildup that could interfere with its performance. By following these steps, you can ensure a safe and effective cooking experience with an induction cooker.
